comment_text: While we wait for Musk's amazing Starship rocket, today's space program centrally depends on the original 1960s Mercury and Gemini rocket, Atlas and Titan. And we beg Russians for 1950s Soyuz to lift our heaviest loads. We use the ancient Mercury and Gemini, why not the newer and best, Apollo F-1 rocket? Why beg the Russians for their stronger rocket than our Gemini Titan? The Apollo F-1 remains the strongest rocket ever! F-1 the only 100% reliable rocket ever! 65 engines, 13 flights, zero F-1 failures! To the moon with five F-1 not 39 raptors, and no risky refueling in orbit! NASA planned the F-1 to take us to Mars by 1985, why didn't we use it? Why not now? With 39 F-1 we could do far MORE than Musk's Starship! Why did we waste 15 years waiting for the Shuttle rocket? A weak hydrogen burner needing solid fuel boosters. We could have launched Shuttle on 2 or 3 F-1. Why did we wait 60 years for Musk, Bezos and ULA to replace the Apollo F-1? We centrally use old '60s Mercury, Gemini, we discard America's best, Apollo and use Russian Soyuz. And old late 60s Shuttle weak hydrogen rocket is now back on the new SLS to take us back to the moon - weak, so with solid fuel boosters. Why not use the tested and proved, 100% reliable F-1 that already took us to the moon? What is the hidden scandal of the F-1 that it's the only '60s rocket we don't use? One thing this video touched on so briefly it was easy to miss: the technology developed for the Apollo program was taxpayer-funded, so ALL industry in the US was allowed to use it, so it led to huge economic and scientific advances in the US in the 70s through the 90s (by which time it was the space shuttle program that was providing technology development, but there's some overlap).

E.G. Computers the size of rooms couldn't fit on Apollo; they had to come up with integrated circuits and flight computers— leading to business, medical, scientific, military, and home computing, plus military and civilian aircraft flight computers.

Most of the fire-retardant materials and foams used today by firefighters came from research after the Apollo 1 disaster, continued during the development of the Space Shuttle, because they needed ways to extinguish fires that would be nontoxic, would not require spraying water, and would contain fire as much as possible. I believe the Phoschek dumped by tanker planes over the American west and worldwide today came from this research, and I know firefighters' suits use some of the same materials.

There are so very, very, very many things we use in our everyday lives, from smart phones to microwave ovens, that were developed and invented for and by the space program, that the money spent on it tends to yield dividends worth much more in terms of actual cash and lives impacted. But we don't often hear about it. In fact, that might be a great topic for SciShow!

One thing that I feel wasn't mentioned here is the simple fact that in the VAST majority of cases, the risks involved were explicitly there because we didn't know what could happen. The risks were mitigated later on specifically because we learned that X could happen, or when Y happens Z can happen, and then we developed precautions to solve those problems.

Apollo 1 is a great example. Before Apollo 1, while we conceptually knew that more oxygen meant more fire risk, we didn't really have a great concept of how quickly that scales up or how drastically the fire changes. In Apollo 1, we learned that a pure oxygen atmosphere can combust almost immediately, and that there's effectively 0 chance to save the crew simply because the extreme heat generated killed them almost instantly. After that, while NASA still experimented with higher oxygen levels than normal, there was ALWAYS a substantial amount of noble gas like Nitrogen in the air. I believe a number of their missions ran at 40% oxygen, which is almost twice normal levels, but still represents a drastic cut from 100%.

In essence, we didn't really realize that the risk was there, or at least that big, until the worst happened, and then we started mitigating that risk. The same WILL happen with every new major step in exploration, just like it HAS happened in every past major step in exploration, either physically or technologically. Open sea exploration saw deaths before we learned more, internal combustion engine technology had deaths before we learned more. Mars or Moon colonization WILL have deaths before we learn more. Space stations will have deaths before we learn more. Et cetera.

Even the Apollo Capsule was Dangerous because of the short timeline and "Dead" lines. While the Mercury and Gemini Capsules were stable in Hypersonic, Supersonic and Subsonic flight, the Apollo capsule was unstable in Subsonic Flight. Changes made to add the forward docking port also made the Apollo Capsule unstable in Subsonic flight. While this was an acceptable risk in the Apollo Era, would be unacceptable for an Manned Entry Vehicle. It's Sad that NASA and Boeing would build another Apollo Capsule today, like the Orion and Starliner Capsules when we have the tools and know-how to build Stable Entry Vehicles. Just recently, the Orion Capsule failed it's Abort Test as it tumbled out of control in SubSonic Flight. Tumbling so fast that it would have incapacitated or killed the Astronauts before landing in the Ocean. A properly designed Capsule like the SpaceX Dragon is stable in Hypersonic, Supersonic and Subsonic flight and is therefore safer that the Apollo, Orion and Starliner Capsules.

The Earthrise image DID make a profound change to the way humans envisioned how their planet looked. Images of Earth floating in space had been depicted in sci-fi movies and such for some time, but it is interesting to see how this depiction changed when civilization saw the first Earthrise image from Apollo 8. Take a look at the planets in the original Star Trek (made available on DVD in the 1900s) compared to the BluRays of the same show. The DVDs used the original, pre-Apollo 8 optically generated planets from the 1960s, whereas the BluRays remade the planets with CGI (which did not even exist in the 1960s) to appear more the way Earth looked in the Earthrise images. The profound shift was that clouds played a much bigger role post-1968.

As a person who remembers those days well, I can tell you that the moon landing has touched every aspect of our modern lives. From the technological gains like integrated circuits, and computers, to freeze dried foods and velcro. But also the intangible effects... ‘we can send a man to the moon, so we can___(whatever we set our minds to)’. Science became a magical ‘can do!’ In society, and a source of much optimism during a time when we truly needed it. Science and technology could do anything, it seemed, and we as individuals, by extension, could too. It is that wave of hope... of ‘can do’ that has given us cell phones and internet, self-driving cars, and iPads. It is that optimism that we gained by landing on the moon, that makes us believe science can save us from coronavirus, and that same optimism will make sure it does. We live in a time when our superstitions are trying to suppress our science, but science is truth... and eventually the truth always wins. “One giant leap for Mankind” indeed!

Truly, a fantastic video, thank you Sci Show. I was a child in 1969, and the moon landing is one of my first and very few episodic memories (thanks sci show for the term) of my early days. I can remember sitting with my parents and neighbors, my friends, and we watched the television set for this event. And it sparked in my a curiosity about space, science, physics astronomy , and more that still exists today at 55 years old, Apollo was that powerful. As kids we watched these launches and landings with such keen interest. It was science at work, no boring classroom exercises. And without Apollo, we would not have what we have today. It inspired so many great minds to continue the exploration of space and all that such an endeavor entails.
In the course of my career I had the opportunity to meet numerous people who were celebrities, or persons that were part of making history, from Kings and Queens , prime ministers, and on down the line. I very seldom would ask for an autograph or even go out of my way to engage with that person, but I did so with 3 of the Apollo astronauts, John Glenn, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin. I consider meeting and talking with these 3 explorers as one of the highlights of my life and they are cherished memories.
The Risk was worth the reward. Apollo shaped so much that there is hardly anything we take firxgranted today that wasn't influenced by those missions. Fortunately we had people who were willing to take those risks, even though they did not know the outcome and certainly had no idea how far reaching their contributions would take us as a people. While we laugh about the preconceptions people had before science advanced our knowledge on any given subject, take Columbus, a man much vilified in today's PC world, yet imagine the courage it took to set off in a little wooden boat, to sail the opposite direction people usually did, because many still believed the world was flat, to find a route to the Indies. Essentially that is what the Apollo astronauts did, they climbed into a little metaphorical little wooden boat and went to the moon. That's courage.
Thank you Sci show for keeping this subject alive and well.

Ironically, the Apollo Program would never have happened under a "pure" capitalistic economy. There's a reason NASA is a government agency and the Apollo Program itself was funded completely by the government. Yes, private companies contributed - but only because the government was paying them to do so. Going to the moon? There's no profit in that. Whether it's worth risking human lives is up to the people whose lives are at risk to answer. Whether it's worth risking money is up to the people whose money is at risk to answer.

Sorry to Nick pick a tiny parts of a long video. But I like to appear as bright as you by adding small corrections to a complex subject. Before Apollo, the computer used for guidance were not using discrete transistors.
They were using valves and tubes with fluids, like in automatic transmission up to 1998 where microprocessors started to replace progressively that technology.
The electronic equivalent was using operational amplifiers to create PID loops.
The computers were not digital, they were not using binary values to express quantities.
The analog computers used slowly charging capacitors to create filters and integrators. The voltage sampled at specific time was the answer of a computation.
At the beginning, engineers were asked to use only fundamental logic gates, AND, OR and the NOT.
This rule was to switch vendor easily. More complex chips were authorized over time (flip flop / D latch, multiplexer, etc) as silicon valley demonstrated higher reliability with compact circuits.
However, there was no microprocessors yet. The first one was not designed for space exploration, but for a calculator made in Japan.
NASA didn't order special technology. They were looking at the catalog of parts already in the market and designed the digital computer from standard parts.

The Apollo program sought to find microtektites. The US government knew that the geological layer corresponding to the end of the Younger Dryas showed ubiquitous microtektites around Earth. This suggests that the Sun hit Earth with a micronova. Finding microtektites on the Moon would confirm this hypothesis. All Apollo missions found the Moon had been splattered with glass, microtektites. This prompted multi-decade long building programs putting infrastructure underground so that some aspects of our civilization would survive the next, and imminent solar micronova. It's roughly on a 12,000 year cycle.

I was surprised that there was not a discussion of "spinoffs" and ROI (Return On Investment), as both the Apollo program in its entirety, and current projects today, all have insanely high spinoff and ROI rates.

Quotes from nss.org (https://space.nss.org/settlement/nasa/spaceresvol4/newspace3.html):

"Spinoffs from NASA's development of space technology not only provide products and services to the society but also are a significant boon to the American economy. [...] Estimates of the return on investment in the space program range from $7 for every $1 spent on the Apollo Program to $40 for every $1 spent on space development today."

"In words President George Bush quoted from a news magazine, the Apollo Program was "the best return on investment since Leonardo da Vinci bought himself a sketchpad" (Chandler 1989)."

For more information worth noting, follow the link below:

The ROI Of Space Exploration (https://www.investopedia.com/financial-edge/0812/the-roi-of-space-exploration.aspx)"

Although I did enjoy this episode, I feel like you missed the opportunity to really analyze the question of the value of the Apollo program on a more objective level. Subjectively determining that the program was worth it because it was hard seems to only really scratch the surface and doesn't add anything new to the discussion. We already knew it was hard and we already knew it was politically motivated by the Cold War.

What really would have been interesting is exploring the innovations associated with the Gemini and Apollo programs that have resulted in the betterment of all mankind along with the missed opportunity cost of diverting such a large amount of public resources to one program. As contemporary critics had pointed out, what would those vast public funds have achieved if not invested in the space program? Were we on the verge of scientific breakthroughs that fizzled or were delayed because of a lack of public funding? Could we have improved the socioeconomic status of our citizens reducing poverty and generating long-lasting economic opportunity? These are relevant questions that demonstrate value much more than the subjective conclusion that it was worth it because it was hard. Lots of things are hard that don't really contribute to making it worth doing. Vietnam was hard, but did that make it a valuable endeavor?

There is one aspect of SciShow's analysis that should you should have spent more time on to demonstrate the value of Apollo program: the switch to integrated circuits in the aeronautical guidance systems. Integrated circuits have revolutionized modern human life. Innovations like this that were spurred by the space program objectively demonstrate value. That the motivation and the resources were both available to support innovation and problem-solving gives credence to the argument that the program advanced human progress and therefore worthy of the tremendous cost of the program. I would like to have heard more about lasting innovations that came out of the Apollo program or were inspired by the need to solve the problems associated with space travel, like the ones outlined here: https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/80660main_ApolloFS.pdf. I think SciShow missed an opportunity here. Time for a follow-up?

27:48 I think it's because there haven't been any big ideological battles between powers of the same levels of technology. The Cold War wasn't just a staring contest between two great powers, but two ideologies. Both sides told their people that their very way of life was at stake. There will always be people who will take the risk, who want to learn, and who want to explore. But the people with the power, who hold the pursestrings, mostly cared about preserving their own power. The "discovery" of the New World wasn't because of the inherent need to explore the world. Spain funded the fleet to circumvent the Ottoman Empire's control of the trade routes to the East. As an Islamic nation, the Ottomans were seen as inherent and ideological opponents to Spain in the hyper-religious world of the 1400s. Unlike Venice, Spain took the risk. Europeans didn't force their way through the rest of the New World to learn new things, they did so because of the economic benefits. The government focus, obsession, and competitiveness that allowed Apollo to be funded were the same that lead to the Red Scare and the countless dead in the proxy wars of the Cold War.

I am a big fan of Apollo, but in some important ways it was a huge mistake. Apollo was perhaps the most important battle of the Cold War and for that reason alone it was worth the money. Many in America at the time had the fear that if the Russians beat us to the Moon it would lead to Russian global domination and ultimately a Russian flag flying over DC. Apollo stopped that (even if it was only a fear).

However, to succeed and beat the Russians Apollo had to be done the wrong way that led to only short term gains in human space exploration. To win the race to the Moon, Apollo had a blank check book and only a few short years. They were wonderful years of exciting space spectaculars. In fact one Apollo astronaut reflected that "ït was like someone took a decade out of the 21st century and inserted it into the 20th century." But to win the race the Americans had to adopt a basically socialistic methodology. The Americans made the Apollo program a centralized government led and funded program that brought nearly all the nation's technical and engineering might to bear on reaching the Moon in a few short years. Aerospace companies were selected and funded to follow NASA's lead to develop and build the spacecraft that would take Americans to the Moon. By doing this, we were essentially playing by the Russian's socialist rules (and beating them at it!).

The incredible irony here is that that is the strongest capitalist system in the world was not using a free market economy or relying on competition, but socialism, to accomplish Apollo's goal. This led to amazing results and the United States winning the race handily (with special thanks to Russian problems with Soyuz and the N1 rocket). But it also led to the sad downfall of Apollo after winning the race. You see, since Apollo was government funded and directed to accomplish a single goal, there was no way for human spaceflight to continue without massive government funding and control. That meant that politics would be the controlling factor and when ten percent of the national budget was going to Apollo, once the goal was reached, the funding would disappear, and it did. NASA even had several billion dollar lawn ornaments that would never go to the Moon as a result.

Because the aerospace industry grew up on government contracts, it never had the pressure of competition to make it efficient and cost-effective. All it wanted was another source of income after Apollo and so continued it's love-affair with the government and military contracts. In fact, efficiency and cost-effectiveness became the enemy of increased profit for less effort and advances in human spaceflight came to a screeching halt. Instead of going to Mars after Apollo we built a super expensive and unsafe system to go in endless loops around the Earth. This was the mistake of Apollo. When Apollo ended, US human spaceflight ended. The huge investment of Apollo may have won the Cold War, but the cost was not leveraged for the future. Apollo was abandoned because it was designed to really only do one thing, and very expensively.

What should have been done at the start of Apollo was for the government to offer a series of prize competitions for the first company that could develop the least expensive rocket to lift a sizeable payload to orbit, spacecraft to carry a crew, rocket to carry the spacecraft from Earth orbit to the Moon, and perhaps a spacecraft to land on the Moon and return (if the earlier spacecraft could not), as well as spacesuits, lunar rovers, and lunar bases. The winners of these competitions would be guaranteed a certain number of flights (but not all of them!). This could have produced a healthy launch industry that would have grown to become more robust than Apollo and able to accomplish more at a lower cost. Since it would be commercial, competition would drive each company to improve their product and lower their cost. Some would fail, but others would succeed. This could have led to a lower cost for Apollo and enabled NASA to continue flying Apollo missions, or better yet allowed the launch industry to handle the hardware and have NASA just purchasing the services from the best providers.

Following a capitalistic model for Apollo might have taken longer but it would have cost the US taxpayer less and resulted in a more diversified launch industry capable of building bases on the Moon and exploring Mars long ago. My guess is that the US would still have beaten the Russians to the Moon AND left us with a viable growing human spaceflight capability for a much lower cost.

I'll just be a bit contrarian and say this: I tend not to dwell too much on hypotheticals because they are just that - hypotheticals. I'd even give a different answer - was it a bad idea? Potentially yes. We don't have the ability to travel back time and see what would've happened if we never tried.
Now, can we all see the huge transformative benefits and overall awesomeness of what all these people managed to accomplish for the entire humankind? F* yeah!


But you see how this leads to survivorship bias. We can now say that it was a good idea and that it was all worth it because of the huge perceived benefits that came from it. But it's a program so huge that no single person can have an entire adequate grasp of all it's component parts, what was sacrificed, what we didn't do in order for this to happen, what other routes we might have gone, etc etc. And quite frankly, it's useless to dwell on all that. The fact is, we did it, and we got plenty out for having done it.


Because you see, this question could be posited for almost everything. Was messing with nuclear physics a good idea? Was industrialization a good one? Was adopting capitalism a good idea? The exploration around topics from macro to micro are interesting in themselves, but we don't have definitive answers. But it's perhaps our role to keep exploring. It's potentially why we are here... until we get to a definitive nope. xD

The first groups of NASA astronauts were first and foremost testpilots and war-proven combat pilots. Their risk tolerance was exceptionally high, because of all they had experienced prior to becoming astronauts.
Later astronaut classes were first and foremost accomplished scientists and engineers. Their risk tolerance was / is considerably smaller and their approach to risk-mitigation is very analytical and based on running every conceivable test / simulation over and over before even climbing aboard a spaceship.
The entire Apollo program lasted 20 years. Today every single space mission has a preparation / ramp up period of 2-4 years!
Both Hadfield and Massamino state in their books that they were very aware that they were about to get aboard a megaton bomb and that by day's end they would either be in space or dead.

What a COMPLEX MULTIDIMENSIONAL QUESTION!  Also in the mix is,..."hindsight is 2020".  "Necessity is the Mother of Invention".  Imagine, tomorrow, we find that a monster asteroid is heading straight to Earth, and we have only 7 years to find a "solution".  Back in the 1950s and 1960s, as children, we were instructed to "duck and cover", to be ready for nuclear annihilation.  This conjures up the world mindset back then.  Today,  no one would say, "We can't afford to finance a space program to stop the asteroid".  (Although, many people are doing precisely that with regards to climate change).  But climate change is a very complex topic, (which can confuse a lot of people, especially if they don't have any formal science education), compared to an obvious rock coming your way.  So, was Apollo worth it?  Yes.  And great SciShow episode!!
